Q1: What is functionalism in simple words?
>! Functionalism is about how different parts of society help keep the whole society working well. !<

Q2: What is one problem critics point out about functionalism?
>! Critics say functionalism ignores fighting and chaos in society, or that it assumes everyone agrees on values. !<

Q3: Which book did Durkheim write to explain his theory of religion?
>! He wrote the book "The Elementary Forms of Religious Life". !<

Q4: How did Durkheim define religion?
>! Durkheim defined religion as a system of beliefs and practices about sacred things. !<

Q5: What are "sacred things" according to Durkheim? Give one example.
>! Sacred things are special things that are set apart and considered forbidden to touch casually, like a holy book or a sacred river. !<

Q6: What are "profane things" according to Durkheim? Give one example.
>! Profane things are ordinary, everyday things, like tap water or a normal stone. !<

Q7: What is one way sacred things are kept separate from profane things?
>! Sacred things are protected by strict rules or taboos, so profane things cannot touch them easily. !<

Q8: Does something have to be useful to be sacred? Why?
>! No, usefulness does not make something sacred. Even a simple stone can be sacred if people believe it is special. !<

Q9: Can something that is profane become sacred? How?
>! Yes, things can become sacred from profane through special rituals or ceremonies. !<

Q10: Which primitive tribe in Australia did Durkheim study to understand religion?
>! He studied the Arunta tribe. !<

Q11: What is a totem in the Arunta tribe?
>! A totem is a plant or animal symbol that represents a clan (a group within the tribe). !<

Q12: What did the Arunta people carve their totems on, besides flags?
>! They carved them on a sacred object called a churunga. !<

Q13: What did Durkheim conclude about what people are truly worshipping when they worship their totem?
>! Durkheim concluded they are worshipping their own clan or society. !<

Q14: What did Durkheim mean by saying "God is society divinized"?
>! He meant that the idea of God is really the idea of society made holy or divine. !<

Q15: How does religion help people know what is right and wrong?
>! Religion provides people with a shared sense of morality and ideas about good and bad conduct. !<

Q16: How does religion help society maintain control over people?
>! Religion gives strict rules and taboos, and religious punishments are often seen as stronger than legal ones. !<

Q17: Durkheim said the relationship between a person and God is similar to the relationship between a person and what else?
>! It is similar to the relationship between a person and society. !<

Q18: How can religion help people feel strong during sad times, like when someone dies?
>! Religion can offer ideas like afterlife or soul, and people come together in rituals to support each other. !<

Q19: What is "collective effervescence"? Give an example.
>! Collective effervescence is a strong feeling of energy and excitement that happens when people come together in rituals with singing, chanting, or dancing, like chanting "Jai Mata Di" together. !<

Q20: What is the main way religion helps society stay together?
>! Religion creates social solidarity and helps unite members into a single moral community. !<

Q21: What process seemed to be happening to religion in Durkheim's time in Europe?
>! The process of secularization was happening, where religion seemed to be declining. !<

Q22: Did Durkheim believe religion was dying out in modern society? What did he think was happening instead?
>! No, he thought the old sacred things were being replaced by new sacred things. !<

Q23: What are two examples of "new sacreds" in modern society according to Durkheim?
>! Examples include the national flag, national anthem, or the constitution. !<

Q24: Why are new sacred symbols needed in modern society?
>! Modern society has many different kinds of people and religions, so they need new shared symbols to bring them together. !<

Q25: What is a major criticism of Durkheim's theory of religion regarding fighting?
>! Critics say he ignores the violence and conflict that religion can cause throughout history, like wars and riots. !<

Q26: How did critics describe Durkheim's method of studying the Arunta tribe?
>! They called him an "armchair sociologist" because he didn't visit the tribe himself but read about them from others' writings. !<

Q27: Give an example from daily life that shows the sacred and profane are not always completely separate.
>! Examples include notebooks (related to knowledge/Vidya but used daily) or money (related to Lakshmi Mata but used casually). !<

Q28: Why do some people say Durkheim's theory is not good enough to explain big, complex religions like Hinduism or Islam?
>! They say it was based on a simple tribal religion and doesn't fully explain the many different ideas, books, and groups in large world religions. !<

Q29: How can religion be a source of unfairness or bad practices, according to critics? Give an example.
>! Critics say religion has sometimes supported bad practices like Sati, child marriage, or untouchability. !<

Q30: What do critics say about how religion treats women?
>! Critics say most major religions are patriarchal and have rules or traditions that harm women. !<

Q31: What is the name of Durkheim's first major book about how society works?
>! It is called "Division of Labor in Society". !<

Q32: What does "division of labor" mean in a simple way?
>! It means breaking down a job or activity into smaller parts, with different people doing each part. !<

Q33: How did economists like Adam Smith mostly see the division of labor?
>! They saw it as a way to make production faster and more efficient. !<

Q34: How was Durkheim's view of the division of labor different from the economists' view?
>! Durkheim saw division of labor as benefiting the whole society in many ways, not just making more things. !<

Q35: What big question did Durkheim try to answer about modern society in his book on division of labor?
>! He wanted to know how modern society stays together when people are more focused on themselves (individualism) rather than the group. !<

Q36: How did traditional society differ from modern society in how people thought about themselves and the group?
>! Traditional society had a collective orientation (group focus), while modern society has heightened individualism (self focus). !<

Q37: Why does Durkheim believe religion helps create a shared sense of morality?
>! He thinks religion provides common ideas and examples of what is considered good or bad behaviour for everyone in the society. !<

Q38: How does the energy from collective effervescence help connect people in a group?
>! The shared experience and energy during collective rituals strengthen the feelings of belonging and connection between people and their community. !<

Q39: What might happen to a society if people stopped believing in anything sacred or having shared sacred symbols?
>! Durkheim might say the society could lose its sense of unity and shared identity, making it harder to hold together. !<

Q40: How does the idea of sacred things relate to rules and prohibitions in society?
>! Things defined as sacred are protected by strong rules and taboos; breaking these rules is often seen as very serious. !<

Q41: Think about something in your school or family that is treated with special respect or has rules around it, making it seem almost "sacred" in a small way. Give an example.
>! (Example: A national flag hoisted in the school assembly; a special family heirloom that must be handled carefully) !<

Q42: Why do some critics say Durkheim's focus on the positive functions of religion is one-sided?
>! They say he focuses too much on how religion unites people and ignores the ways it has caused terrible conflicts, violence, and oppression throughout history. !<

Q43: How does the division of labor help people in modern society depend on each other?
>! When people specialize in different tasks, they need others who specialize in different tasks to meet their needs, which creates interdependence and helps hold society together. !<

Q44: Imagine your school had no division of labor, and one teacher had to teach all subjects, clean the school, manage the library, and cook the food. What problems might happen?
>! The school would likely be very inefficient; subjects might not be taught well, and tasks would be missed or done poorly because one person cannot do everything effectively. !<

Q45: Why is it important for a society to have moments or events where everyone comes together, like religious festivals or national holidays?
>! Coming together helps create a sense of shared identity and belonging, strengthens the bonds between people, and reminds them they are part of a larger community. !<
